ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: You translate the entirety of the Beowulf poem from Old English into modern English over the course of the semester (about 400 lines a week). There are some auxiliary texts and secondary readings, as well as an in-class presentation and short paper. There is a final exam.

Summary: A course based around the translation of Beowulf, that used the poem as the springboard for discussion about broader interpretive issues which ran the gamut from Anglo-Saxon culture and Anglo-Saxon literature, to modern literary critique of Beowulf, and Philology.I would highly recommend this course to a student, assuming that the student was really willing to work hard and throw themselves into what could be an all-consuming process of translation, re-translation and interpretation.In that vein: I'm saying that "work load" and "difficulty" (below) were "appropriate" because I think they were given what we were trying to accomplish, but it should be noted that this course required significantly more time/work than others I have taken this year.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Both of Prof. Frank's courses opened up the world of Old English for me this year. I still don't know how I will incorporate this into my dissertation, but I am very glad that my understanding of "English Literature" will forever extend back far enough to include Anglo-Saxon literature.
